Description: Necklace (?): a string composed of beads of various shapes and a number of materials. There are two oblate beads, one of amethyst and another of green feldspar, and a tooth-shaped shell-bead of polished pink limestone (?). The string includes three bone disc beads, one black steatite short barrel, one turquoise short barrel and a gold cylinder formed from a strip of gold folded over. Ninety-eight long, standard and short truncated convex bicone beads are of cornelian, as is the shell-shaped amuletic pendant. The string is completed by one long cylinder, two long convex bicone beads, one conical bead, a few discs and two notched amuletic beads, all of green glazed composition.
Curator's comments: Registered as 'the tomb of the Prince's Retainer Ankhu'. Also from this burial: amuletic string (1926,0728.146), beads (1926,0728.145 & 1926,0728.148). For tooth-shaped shell-beads, cf. W. M. F. Petrie, ‘Amulets’, London (1914), pl.XIV, 108c: 'Nerita crassilabrum' shell. Twelfth Dynasty. For shell-shaped amuletic pendants, cf. W. M. F. Petrie, ‘Amulets’, London (1914), 111e-j: 'Cardium edule' shells. Bibliography: 'British Museum Quarterly' 1 (1926-7), pl.XXXVb; H. Frankfort in 'Journal of Egyptian Archaeology' 16 (1930), 213-19, describes the excavations without mentioning this particular burial.
Bibliographic references: Andrews 1981 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities. Jewellery I (417)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2005 Oct-present, Lincoln City and Council Museum, LT Loan
